Welcome to the wonderful world =
of JUnit!

There are many useful websites for the JUnit user, but perhaps t=
he two
main ones are http://www.junit.org/ and http://www.google.com/. The
=
JUnit site maintains a lot of useful information and links to other
resourc=
es. Many of the articles there are directed towards the
beginner and will h=
elp you greatly as you learn about JUnit. Google is
useful when there's som=
ething you need, but don't know what it is.
Just type a description in, pre=
ss enter and see how much help it can
be. I've found quite a few useful thi=
ngs that way. Another tip with
Google is to search on the specific error me=
ssage that you have, often
you'll find forum discussions about that exact e=
rror, with a good
chance of a solution being given as well.

As you learn a=
nd start having questions, you will also find the JUnit
FAQ very helpful. T=
he questions that it answers really are the
frequent ones that most of us h=
ad asked or wondered about and Mike
Clark does a wonderful job of collating=
 it. Here is a link:

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm

When yo=
u are ready to start asking more questions on the JUnit mailing
list, pleas=
e consider following all of the advice in Eric Raymond's
very helpful docum=
ent: "How to ask questions the smart way", available
at his website. Here i=
s a link:

http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

As far as bo=
oks are concerned, I recommend Pragmatic Unit Testing by
Hunt and Thomas fo=
r beginners. JUnit recipes by Rainsberger is good
once you're past the basi=
cs. There are other good books out there, but
these are my recommendations.=


I hope that this helps.

Simon
